metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: HTML HSL and HSLA Colors
HSL stands for hue, saturation, and lightness.
content.html: HSL stands for hue, saturation, and lightness.

content.text: HSLA color values are an extension of HSL with an Alpha channel (opacity).
content.html: HSLA color values are an extension of HSL with an Alpha channel (opacity).

content.text: HSL Color Values
In HTML, a color can be specified using hue, saturation, and lightness (HSL) in the form:
content.html: In HTML, a color can be specified using hue, saturation, and lightness (HSL) in the form:

content.text: hsl( hue , saturation , lightness )
content.html: hsl(hue, saturation, lightness)

content.text: Hue is a degree on the color wheel from 0 to 360. 0 is red, 120 is green, and 240 is blue.
content.html: Hue is a degree on the color wheel from 0 to 360. 0 is red, 120 is green, and 240 is blue.

content.text: Saturation is a percentage value. 0% means a shade of gray, and 100% is the full color.
content.html: Saturation is a percentage value. 0% means a shade of gray, and 100% is the full color.

content.text: Lightness is also a percentage value. 0% is black, and 100% is white.
content.html: Lightness is also a percentage value. 0% is black, and 100% is white.

content.text: Experiment by mixing the HSL values below:
content.html: Experiment by mixing the HSL values below:
hsl(0, 100%, 50%)

content.text: HUE
content.html: HUE

content.text: SATURATION
content.html: SATURATION

content.text: LIGHTNESS
content.html: LIGHTNESS

content.code_html:
hsl(0, 100%, 50%)
hsl(240, 100%, 50%)
hsl(147, 50%, 47%)
hsl(300, 76%, 72%)
hsl(39, 100%, 50%)
hsl(248, 53%, 58%)

content.text: Saturation
Saturation can be described as the intensity of a color.
content.html: Saturation can be described as the intensity of a color.

content.text: 100% is pure color, no shades of gray.
content.html: 100% is pure color, no shades of gray.

content.text: 50% is 50% gray, but you can still see the color.
content.html: 50% is 50% gray, but you can still see the color.

content.text: 0% is completely gray; you can no longer see the color.
content.html: 0% is completely gray; you can no longer see the color.

content.code_html:
hsl(0, 100%, 50%)
hsl(0, 80%, 50%)
hsl(0, 60%, 50%)
hsl(0, 40%, 50%)
hsl(0, 20%, 50%)
hsl(0, 0%, 50%)

content.text: Lightness

The lightness of a color can be described as how much light you want to give the color, where 0% means no light (black), 50% means 50% light (neither dark nor light), and 100% means full lightness (white).
content.html: The lightness of a color can be described as how much light you want to give the color, where 0% means no light (black), 50% means 50% light (neither dark nor light), and 100% means full lightness (white).

content.code_html:
hsl(0, 100%, 0%)
hsl(0, 100%, 25%)
hsl(0, 100%, 50%)
hsl(0, 100%, 75%)
hsl(0, 100%, 90%)
hsl(0, 100%, 100%)

content.text: Shades of Gray
Shades of gray are often defined by setting the hue and saturation to 0, and adjusting the lightness from 0% to 100% to get darker/lighter shades:
content.html: Shades of gray are often defined by setting the hue and saturation to 0, and adjusting the lightness from 0% to 100% to get darker/lighter shades:

content.code_html:
hsl(0, 0%, 20%)
hsl(0, 0%, 30%)
hsl(0, 0%, 40%)
hsl(0, 0%, 60%)
hsl(0, 0%, 70%)
hsl(0, 0%, 90%)

content.text: HSLA Color Values
HSLA color values are an extension of HSL color values, with an Alpha channel - which specifies the opacity for a color.
content.html: HSLA color values are an extension of HSL color values, with an Alpha channel - which specifies the opacity for a color.

content.text: An HSLA color value is specified with:
content.html: An HSLA color value is specified with:

content.text: hsla( hue, saturation , lightness, alpha )
content.html: hsla(hue, saturation, lightness, alpha)

content.text: The alpha parameter is a number between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (not transparent at all):
content.html: The alpha parameter is a number between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (not transparent at all):

content.text: Experiment by mixing the HSLA values below:
content.html: Experiment by mixing the HSLA values below:
hsla(0, 100%, 50%, 0.5)

content.text: HUE
content.html: HUE

content.text: SATURATION
content.html: SATURATION

content.text: LIGHTNESS
content.html: LIGHTNESS

content.text: ALPHA
content.html: ALPHA

content.code_html:
hsla(9, 100%, 64%, 0)
hsla(9, 100%, 64%, 0.2)
hsla(9, 100%, 64%, 0.4)
hsla(9, 100%, 64%, 0.6)
hsla(9, 100%, 64%, 0.8)
hsla(9, 100%, 64%, 1)

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which one of the following color values will result in a black color?
content.html: Which one of the following color values will result in a black color?
